issue.title: Compile minpack

labels.name: SciPy
labels.description: issues related to enable LFortran to compile the entire FORTRAN codebase in SciPy

issue.body:
### TODO to public a blog post

* [x] add CI: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1182
* [ ] get rid of all the three "XX" commits in the minpack repo (by fixing it in LFortran)
* [ ] get all examples working
* [ ] should run at our CI correctly for a few weeks to reach "beta" (ideally 2 months, but we can "overwrite" this requirement)
* [ ] write up a blog post and announce

### Tracking examples
- [x] examples_hybrd
- [x] examples_hybrd1
- [ ] examples_lmder1
   - #1150 
   - #1133
- [x] examples_lmdif1
  - #1122
- [ ] examples_primes
   - #967 


---------




### Highest Priority

The code now compiles to binary (with just minimal source modifications, see below), but doesn't produce correct answers due to:

* [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/971 (fixed by #972)
* [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/976

And perhaps other issues that we have not identified yet.

---------

### AST->ASR

These must be fixed, but the workaround is relatively simple by modifying Minpack sources, so are lower priority than the above.

Known TODO items for ASR (we commented out code for now):

* [ ] equivalence statement
* [x] statement functions (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/911)
* [x] implicit external (#950)
* [ ] implied do loop (#981)
* [x] do loop non-constant integer increment (#909, #946, #979)
* [x] argument callback (undeclared)
* [x] external function declared as "double precision f", when it should probably be "external f"
* [x] implicit interface failure
* [ ] LFortran also prints several warnings for missing features that are ignored, so we have to fix those
* [x] The -I and -J options (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/930)
* [ ] `format()`: this is not strictly needed to get the correct answer and might not even be needed for SciPy, but it would be good to have it, so that things format on the screen correctly


---------------

Steps:

https://github.com/certik/minpack/tree/scipy

```console
git clone https://github.com/certik/minpack.git
cd minpack
git checkout -t origin/scipy
FC=lfortran cmake .
make
ctest
```

All files compile to ASR as of 04d5732088ba195865ee9ccf322a4eea55070424, and when compiled sequentially, there is a failure in the LLVM backend:
```console
$ make
[  2%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/minpack.f90.o
[  4%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/covar.f.o
[  6%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/errjac.f.o
[  8%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/hybipt.f.o
[ 10%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o
Internal Compiler Error: Unhandled exception
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/bin/lfortran.cpp", line 1726
    return compile_to_object_file(arg_file, outfile, false,
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/bin/lfortran.cpp", line 733
    result = fe.get_asr2(input, lm, diagnostics);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/fortran_evaluator.cpp", line 227
    Result<ASR::TranslationUnit_t*> res2 = get_asr3(*ast, diagnostics);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/fortran_evaluator.cpp", line 249
    compiler_options.symtab_only, compiler_options);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_to_asr.cpp", line 53
    auto res = body_visitor(al, ast, diagnostics, unit, compiler_options, template_type_parameters);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 1685
    b.template_type_parameters = template_type_parameters;
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 106
    visit_ast(*x.m_items[i]);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4694
    void visit_ast(const ast_t &b) { visit_ast_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4652
    case astType::mod: { v.visit_mod((const mod_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4702
    void visit_program_unit(const program_unit_t &b) { visit_program_unit_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4306
    case program_unitType::Subroutine: { v.visit_Subroutine((const Subroutine_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 975
    transform_stmts(body, x.n_body, x.m_body);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 83
    this->visit_stmt(*m_body[i]);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4737
    void visit_stmt(const stmt_t &b) { visit_stmt_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4412
    case stmtType::Format: { v.visit_Format((const Format_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_common_visitor.h", line 872
    throw SemanticError("The value in data must be a constant",
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/libasr/asr.h", line 40
    LFORTRAN_ASSERT(is_a<T>(*f));
AssertFailed: is_a<T>(*f)
make[2]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

Currently as of 88b1ef7c5ea99fe40aa05190a68634fbc4e1497e it fails with:

```console
$ make
Scanning dependencies of target minpack
[  2%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/minpack.f90.o
[  4%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/covar.f.o
[  6%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/errjac.f.o
[  8%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/hybipt.f.o
[ 10%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/bin/lfortran.cpp", line 1726
    return compile_to_object_file(arg_file, outfile, false,
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/bin/lfortran.cpp", line 733
    result = fe.get_asr2(input, lm, diagnostics);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/fortran_evaluator.cpp", line 227
    Result<ASR::TranslationUnit_t*> res2 = get_asr3(*ast, diagnostics);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/fortran_evaluator.cpp", line 249
    compiler_options.symtab_only, compiler_options);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_to_asr.cpp", line 53
    auto res = body_visitor(al, ast, diagnostics, unit, compiler_options, template_type_parameters);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 1812
    b.template_type_parameters = template_type_parameters;
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 114
    visit_ast(*x.m_items[i]);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4694
    void visit_ast(const ast_t &b) { visit_ast_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4652
    case astType::mod: { v.visit_mod((const mod_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4702
    void visit_program_unit(const program_unit_t &b) { visit_program_unit_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4306
    case program_unitType::Subroutine: { v.visit_Subroutine((const Subroutine_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 990
    transform_stmts(body, x.n_body, x.m_body);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_body_visitor.cpp", line 90
    this->visit_stmt(*m_body[i]);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4737
    void visit_stmt(const stmt_t &b) { visit_stmt_t(b, self()); }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/ast.h", line 4412
    case stmtType::Format: { v.visit_Format((const Format_t &)x); return; }
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_common_visitor.h", line 917
    current_body->push_back(al, assign_stmt);
  File "/Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/lfortran/src/lfortran/semantics/ast_common_visitor.h", line 917
    current_body->push_back(al, assign_stmt);
  Binary file "/usr/lib/system/libsystem_platform.dylib", local address: 0x1803244e3
Segfault: Signal SIGSEGV (segmentation fault) received
make[2]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

which is a slight regression caused by #864. As of 8e41e7f7e (a slightly prior commit) the error is:
```console
$ make
[  2%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/minpack.f90.o
[  4%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/covar.f.o
[  6%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/errjac.f.o
[  8%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/hybipt.f.o
[ 10%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o
semantic error: Object type ArrayItem is not implemented yet.
  --> /Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/minpack/src/lhesfcn.f:64:12
   |
64 |       data y(1),y(2),y(3),y(4),y(5),y(6),y(7),y(8),y(9),y(10),y(11),
   |            ^^^^ 


Note: if any of the above error or warning messages are not clear or are lacking
context please report it to us (we consider that a bug that needs to be fixed).
make[2]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```
Which shows where the issue is.



----------------

*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/664

It would be very useful to have LFortran able to compile Minpack, currently it fails with commit 74d6438a8

```
❯ lfortran --version
LFortran version: 0.14.0-1345-g74d6438a8
Platform: Linux
Default target: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
❯ fpm build --compiler lfortran
minpack.f90                            failed.
[   7%]Compiling...
semantic error: Value of a parameter variable must evaluate to a compile time constant
  --> ././src/minpack.f90:20:5
   |
20 |     real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = dpmpar(1) !! the machine precision
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 


Note: if any of the above error or warning messages are not clear or are lacking
context please report it to us (we consider that a bug that needs to be fixed).
```

With a minor patch:

```diff
diff --git a/src/minpack.f90 b/src/minpack.f90
index 65fe5b1..ad60201 100644
--- a/src/minpack.f90
+++ b/src/minpack.f90
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ module minpack_module
                                                    tiny(1.0_wp), &
                                                    huge(1.0_wp)] !! machine constants
 
-    real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = dpmpar(1) !! the machine precision
+    real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = epsilon(1.0_wp) !! the machine precision
     real(wp), parameter, private :: one = 1.0_wp
     real(wp), parameter, private :: zero = 0.0_wp
 
```

I'm getting an error for the procedure pointer

```
❯ fpm build --compiler lfortran
minpack.f90                            failed.
[   7%]Compiling...
semantic error: Type not implemented yet.
   --> ./src/minpack.f90:438:9
    |
438 |         procedure(func) :: fcn !! the user-supplied subroutine which
    |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 


```

body:
The ASR for the loop looks like this:
```clojure
(DoLoop 
                        ((Var 2 i) 
                        (IntegerConstant 1 (Integer 4 [])) 
                        (IntegerConstant 10 (Integer 4 [])) 
                        (Var 2 n)) 
                        [(GoToTarget 
                            100 
                            100
                        )]
                    )
```
And after all transformations, when LLVM gets to it:
```clojure
[(If 
                        (IntegerCompare 
                            (Var 2 n) 
                            Gt 
                            (IntegerConstant 0 (Integer 4 [])) 
                            (Logical 1 []) 
                            ()
                        ) 
                        [(= 
                            (Var 2 i) 
                            (IntegerBinOp 
                                (IntegerConstant 1 (Integer 4 [])) 
                                Sub 
                                (Var 2 n) 
                                (Integer 4 []) 
                                ()
                            ) 
                            ()
                        )
                        (WhileLoop 
                            (IntegerCompare 
                                (IntegerBinOp 
                                    (Var 2 i) 
                                    Add 
                                    (Var 2 n) 
                                    (Integer 4 []) 
                                    ()
                                ) 
                                LtE 
                                (IntegerConstant 10 (Integer 4 [])) 
                                (Integer 4 []) 
                                ()
                            ) 
                            [(= 
                                (Var 2 i) 
                                (IntegerBinOp 
                                    (Var 2 i) 
                                    Add 
                                    (Var 2 n) 
                                    (Integer 4 []) 
                                    ()
                                ) 
                                ()
                            )
                            (GoToTarget 
                                100 
                                100
                            )]
                        )] 
                        [(= 
                            (Var 2 i) 
                            (IntegerBinOp 
                                (IntegerConstant 1 (Integer 4 [])) 
                                Sub 
                                (Var 2 n) 
                                (Integer 4 []) 
                                ()
                            ) 
                            ()
                        )
                        (WhileLoop 
                            (IntegerCompare 
                                (IntegerBinOp 
                                    (Var 2 i) 
                                    Add 
                                    (Var 2 n) 
                                    (Integer 4 []) 
                                    ()
                                ) 
                                GtE 
                                (IntegerConstant 10 (Integer 4 [])) 
                                (Integer 4 []) 
                                ()
                            ) 
                            [(= 
                                (Var 2 i) 
                                (IntegerBinOp 
                                    (Var 2 i) 
                                    Add 
                                    (Var 2 n) 
                                    (Integer 4 []) 
                                    ()
                                ) 
                                ()
                            )
                            (GoToTarget 
                                100 
                                100
                            )]
                        )]
                    )]
```
Which seems incorrect, I am surprised to see two loops.

@Smit-create any idea what might be going on in here? I think the issue is with the `GoToTarget` being 100 in both loops, which messes up LLVM. A given number should be there only once in the whole subroutine. It's actually quite non-trivial to duplicate GoTo. But I would not do duplication in the first place, we need to figure out some other way to implement it.

> Which seems incorrect, I am surprised to see two loops.

The two loops appear because of variable value of `n`. At runtime, we will generate doloop according to the value of `n` and so we have an `if` statement to check that and generate appropriate doloop.

If I understand it correctly, it will always generate two loops in LLVM. But only one of them will execute at runtime.

The problem with this approach is that it does not handle GoTo correctly, as now the GoToTarget (labels) get duplicated, which is incorrect --- once we add this check to verify(), it will fail verify().

One fix is to duplicate all gotos correctly. We should implement that anyway, for loop unrolling and such.

But I think we should not create two loops in the first place, we should just add the appropriate logic into one while loop. Although your approach might be faster. 

Another approach is to just allow variable skips in ASR, and write an optional ASR pass to transform this into either two loops or some while logic depending on what the LLVM backend wants.

CC @czgdp1807, what do you think is the best design here?

To move forward, let's implement a minimal solution that works, and once we know what the best ASR design is for this, we'll converge towards it.


Update: in fact, it looks like we already allow variables in the "skip" in ASR, and we handle these in transformations later, based on the above ASR print outs. I think that is the right solution. ASR should be as abstract as possible, but still semantically equivalent to the language. I think in this case it is like that already. So it's just about fixing the ASR passes that transform the do loop into while loops that need to be rewritten. We can have one pass that does just one loop with more complicated logic, and a different pass that does two loops, but must relabel all GoTo. We can use one or the other, or the user can select which one to use.
I left a comment here how to possibly fix it: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/909/files#r1011946352

labels.name: SciPy
labels.description: issues related to enable LFortran to compile the entire FORTRAN codebase in SciPy
